elements.clean_text:
Graphical abstract

An unprecedented solid material obtained by self-assembly of 1-D fishbone-like copper chloride ribbons into a three-dimensional hybrid framework is reported.

Abstract

A novel inorganic-organic hybrid cuprous chloride,     Cu   2   I   Cl ( IN )  (   IN   -   = isonicotinate  ion )  1  , has been hydrothermally synthesized and structurally characterized by the elemental analyses, IR spectrum, TG analysis and the single crystal X-ray diffraction. The structure of 1 exhibits a three-dimensional network built up from unusual fishbone-like copper(I) chloride ribbons bridged by linear isonicotinato ligands. Its luminescent property was also investigated.

<ce:figure>

<ce:section-title>Introduction</ce:section-title><ce:para view="all">Copper halides have been subjected to a vast number of studies due to their structural diversity, originating from the polymerizing metal-halogen-based subunits, that give rise to a variety of applications, e.g., in molecular adsorption, catalysis, electromagnetism, and photochemistry . In particular, polymeric structures based on copper halide units bridged by organic species received increasing interest by reason of the fact that the architectures of copper halides can be tuned at the molecular level so as to design and control, at least partly, the molecular structures of the final products , especially, when the so-called secondary build blocks (SBUs) concept was brought forward and extended by Yaghi and co-workers . Previous studies have shown the tendency of Cu(I) to form one-dimensional (1-D) ribbon like structural motifs with halogens (X<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>=<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>Cl or Br) under hydrothermal conditions , which can be considered as optional candidates for the construction of interesting polymeric frameworks by using them as structural SBUs. Our current research aim is the creative synthesis of desired novel solid materials through extending such 1-D motif into higher dimensions (two-dimensional 2-D or three-dimensional 3-D) via appropriate bridging ligands.</ce:para>
elements.clean_text:
Introduction

Copper halides have been subjected to a vast number of studies due to their structural diversity, originating from the polymerizing metal-halogen-based subunits, that give rise to a variety of applications, e.g., in molecular adsorption, catalysis, electromagnetism, and photochemistry . In particular, polymeric structures based on copper halide units bridged by organic species received increasing interest by reason of the fact that the architectures of copper halides can be tuned at the molecular level so as to design and control, at least partly, the molecular structures of the final products , especially, when the so-called secondary build blocks (SBUs) concept was brought forward and extended by Yaghi and co-workers . Previous studies have shown the tendency of Cu(I) to form one-dimensional (1-D) ribbon like structural motifs with halogens (X=Cl or Br) under hydrothermal conditions , which can be considered as optional candidates for the construction of interesting polymeric frameworks by using them as structural SBUs. Our current research aim is the creative synthesis of desired novel solid materials through extending such 1-D motif into higher dimensions (two-dimensional 2-D or three-dimensional 3-D) via appropriate bridging ligands.

elements.content: <ce:para view="all">Given this consideration, a noticeable linear tridentate ligand isonicotinate ion, which has recently shown interesting properties in constructing extended structures with copper atoms and other SBUs , captured our attention. The IN<ce:sup loc="post">−</ce:sup> contains both a pyridyl group and a carboxylate group in the opposite position of an aromatic ring. It can connect metal ions with its one nitrogen donor and one or two oxygen donors. Several intriguing high-dimensional structures have been obtained in which the isonicotinato ligands display various coordination fashions and abilities . On the other hand, isonicotinato ligand possesses negative charge which may dramatically influence the inorganic copper halide adducts by breaking the charge balance between Cu<ce:sup loc="post">+</ce:sup> and X<ce:sup loc="post">−</ce:sup> in contrast to the neutral organic molecules (for example, the widely used organonitrogen ligands ), and a new copper halide subunit may be thus acquired.</ce:para>
elements.clean_text: Given this consideration, a noticeable linear tridentate ligand isonicotinate ion, which has recently shown interesting properties in constructing extended structures with copper atoms and other SBUs , captured our attention. The IN- contains both a pyridyl group and a carboxylate group in the opposite position of an aromatic ring. It can connect metal ions with its one nitrogen donor and one or two oxygen donors. Several intriguing high-dimensional structures have been obtained in which the isonicotinato ligands display various coordination fashions and abilities . On the other hand, isonicotinato ligand possesses negative charge which may dramatically influence the inorganic copper halide adducts by breaking the charge balance between Cu+ and X- in contrast to the neutral organic molecules (for example, the widely used organonitrogen ligands ), and a new copper halide subunit may be thus acquired.

elements.content:
<ce:para view="all">In this paper, we report a novel 3-D inorganic–organic hybrid cuprous chloride, <mml:math altimg="si4.gif" overflow="scroll">
<mml:mrow>

elements.clean_text: In this paper, we report a novel 3-D inorganic-organic hybrid cuprous chloride,     Cu   2   I   Cl ( IN )  (   IN   -   = isonicotinate  ion )  1  , which is built from new 1-D fishbone-like   {   Cu   2   Cl   }   n   +     ribbons bridged by isonicotinato ligands. To the best of our knowledge, the fishbone-like copper(I) chloride moiety presented in 1 has never been documented before.

elements.content: <ce:section-title>Experimental</ce:section-title><ce:section-title>General procedures</ce:section-title><ce:para view="all">All chemicals purchased were of reagent grade and used without further purification. The hydrothermal reactions were performed in 20<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>ml Teflon-lined stainless steel vessels under autogenous pressure with a filling capacity of ≈60%. Water used in the reactions is distilled water. Elemental analyses (C and N) were performed on a Perkin–Elmer 2400 CHN Elemental Analyzer. Cu was determined by a Leaman inductively coupled plasma (ICP) spectrometer. IR spectrum was recorded in the range 400–4000<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>cm<ce:sup loc="post">−1</ce:sup> on an Alpha Centaurt FT/IR spectrophotometer using KBr pellets. TG analysis was performed on a Perkin–Elmer TGA7 instrument in flowing N<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf> with a heating rate of 10<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>°C<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>min<ce:sup loc="post">−1</ce:sup>. Photoluminescence spectra were measured using a FL-2T2 instrument (SPEX, USA) with 450-W Xenon lamp monochromatized by double grating (1200<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>g/mu).</ce:para>
elements.clean_text:
Experimental

General procedures

All chemicals purchased were of reagent grade and used without further purification. The hydrothermal reactions were performed in 20ml Teflon-lined stainless steel vessels under autogenous pressure with a filling capacity of ~60%. Water used in the reactions is distilled water. Elemental analyses (C and N) were performed on a Perkin-Elmer 2400 CHN Elemental Analyzer. Cu was determined by a Leaman inductively coupled plasma (ICP) spectrometer. IR spectrum was recorded in the range 400-4000cm-1 on an Alpha Centaurt FT/IR spectrophotometer using KBr pellets. TG analysis was performed on a Perkin-Elmer TGA7 instrument in flowing N2 with a heating rate of 10°Cmin-1. Photoluminescence spectra were measured using a FL-2T2 instrument (SPEX, USA) with 450-W Xenon lamp monochromatized by double grating (1200g/mu).

</mml:math> (<ce:bold>1</ce:bold>)</ce:section-title><ce:para view="all">Compound <ce:bold>1</ce:bold> was originally prepared via a self-assembly process under mild hydrothermal condition from the reaction of CuCl, isonicotinic acid, NaCl, and H<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>O in a molar ratio of 2:1:1:555 at 140<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>°C for four days. After slow cooling to room temperature, the resulting orange needles of <ce:bold>1</ce:bold> were collected as a major phase (32% yield on Cu) together with a small quantity of blue block crystals, and then filtered off, washed with distilled water, and dried at ambient temperature. The needles were manually selected for structural determination and further characterization. <ce:italic>Anal.</ce:italic> Calc. for <ce:bold>1</ce:bold>: C, 25.32; N, 4.92; Cu, 44.65. Found: C, 25.19; N, 4.83; Cu, 44.92%. IR (KBr) <ce:italic>ν</ce:italic>/cm<ce:sup loc="post">−1</ce:sup>: 3033w, 1585s, 1547s, 1227s, 1055w, 858w, 764m, 765m, 700s and 527w ().</ce:para>
elements.clean_text:
Synthesis of     Cu   2   I   Cl ( IN )   (1)

Compound 1 was originally prepared via a self-assembly process under mild hydrothermal condition from the reaction of CuCl, isonicotinic acid, NaCl, and H2O in a molar ratio of 2:1:1:555 at 140°C for four days. After slow cooling to room temperature, the resulting orange needles of 1 were collected as a major phase (32% yield on Cu) together with a small quantity of blue block crystals, and then filtered off, washed with distilled water, and dried at ambient temperature. The needles were manually selected for structural determination and further characterization. Anal. Calc. for 1: C, 25.32; N, 4.92; Cu, 44.65. Found: C, 25.19; N, 4.83; Cu, 44.92%. IR (KBr) ν/cm-1: 3033w, 1585s, 1547s, 1227s, 1055w, 858w, 764m, 765m, 700s and 527w ().

elements.content: <ce:para view="all">In order to obtain pure phase product of <ce:bold>1</ce:bold>, several parallel experiments have been done thereafter. It was found that the uniform adducts of <ce:bold>1</ce:bold> could be successfully isolated when the reaction pH values were adjusted to 2.0–3.0 by HCl solution, whereas the reaction time played a less important role that was proved by some successful reactions with heating time between 3 days and 5 days.</ce:para>
elements.clean_text: In order to obtain pure phase product of 1, several parallel experiments have been done thereafter. It was found that the uniform adducts of 1 could be successfully isolated when the reaction pH values were adjusted to 2.0-3.0 by HCl solution, whereas the reaction time played a less important role that was proved by some successful reactions with heating time between 3 days and 5 days.

elements.clean_text:
X-ray crystallography

The data were collected on a Rigaku R-AXIS RAPID IP diffractometer at 293K using graphite-monochromated Mo Kα radiation (λ =0.71073Å) and oscillation scans technique in the range of 3.74°< θ <25.47°. Empirical absorption correction was applied. A total of 5795 (1397 unique, R int =0.1284) reflections were measured. The structure was solved by direct methods using the program SHELXS-97  and refined by full-matrix least-squares methods on F 2 using the SHELXL-97  program package. All of the non-hydrogen atoms were refined anisotropically. Positions of the hydrogen atoms attached to carbon atoms were fixed at their ideal positions. Structure solution and refinement based on 1397 independent reflections with [I >2σ(I)] on 0 restraint and 110 parameters gave R 1 (wR 2)=0.0560 (0.1175). A summary of the crystallographic data and structural determination for compound 1 is provided in  . Selected bond lengths and angles are listed in  .

<ce:section-title>Results and discussion</ce:section-title><ce:para view="all">Single crystal X-ray diffraction analysis<ce:footnote id="fn1">
<ce:label>1</ce:label>

These data can be obtained free of charge at <ce:inter-ref xlink:href="http://www.ccdc.cam.ac.uk/conts/retrieving.html" xlink:type="simple">www.ccdc.cam.ac.uk/conts/retrieving.html</ce:inter-ref> [or from the Cambridge Crystallographic Data Centre, 12, Union Road, Cambridge CB2 1EZ, UK; fax: (internat.) +44 1223/336 033; e-mail: <ce:inter-ref xlink:href="mailto:deposit@ccdc.cam.ac.uk" xlink:type="simple">deposit@ccdc.cam.ac.uk</ce:inter-ref>].</ce:note-para>

 reveals that the structure of compound <ce:bold>1</ce:bold> features a novel 3-D framework constructed from 1-D fishbone-like inorganic ribbons linked via linear bridging ligands IN<ce:sup loc="post">−</ce:sup>. 
<ce:float-anchor refid="fig1"></ce:float-anchor> shows the basic building unit and coordination environments around the copper atoms. Cu(1) atom, residing in a tetrahedral environment, is coordinated by three equivalent chlorine atoms and one nitrogen donor from isonicotinato ligand, whereas Cu(2) atom coordinates to one chlorine donor and two carboxyl oxygen donors from two different IN<ce:sup loc="post">−</ce:sup> to finish its T-shape coordination environment. The Cu(1)–Cl bond lengths are in the range of 2.287–2.625<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>Å (average value 2.425<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>Å), comparable with those found in other reported Cu<ce:sup loc="post">I</ce:sup>–Cl distances . However, the Cu(2)–Cl length of 2.715 is a little longer than the normal Cu<ce:sup loc="post">I</ce:sup>–Cl distance. The tetrahedrally coordinated copper atom is somewhat distorted with Cl–Cu–Cl angles varying from 104.48° to 106.69° and Cl–Cu–N angles of 98.60°, 112.27° and 125.90°, respectively.</ce:para>

Cu(1) atom, residing in a tetrahedral environment, is coordinated by three equivalent chlorine atoms and one nitrogen donor from isonicotinato ligand, whereas Cu(2) atom coordinates to one chlorine donor and two carboxyl oxygen donors from two different IN- to finish its T-shape coordination environment. The Cu(1)-Cl bond lengths are in the range of 2.287-2.625Å (average value 2.425Å), comparable with those found in other reported CuI-Cl distances . However, the Cu(2)-Cl length of 2.715 is a little longer than the normal CuI-Cl distance. The tetrahedrally coordinated copper atom is somewhat distorted with Cl-Cu-Cl angles varying from 104.48° to 106.69° and Cl-Cu-N angles of 98.60°, 112.27° and 125.90°, respectively.

elements.content:
<ce:para view="all">Within the inorganic copper chloride motif, Cu(1) atoms share corners via μ<ce:inf loc="post">4</ce:inf>-Cl to form an infinite 1-D {Cu<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>Cl<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>}<ce:inf loc="post">
<ce:italic>n</ce:italic>
</ce:inf> chain along <ce:italic>b</ce:italic>-axis, which was frequently encountered in copper chlorides . However, each bridging chlorine atom links to an additional Cu(2) atom, generating a novel fishbone-like 1-D copper chloride ribbon (
<ce:float-anchor refid="fig2"></ce:float-anchor>). Further, every isonicotinato ligand nips two Cu(2) atoms being part of two copper chloride ribbons via its carboxyl group, and the remaining nitrogen donor of the ligand anchors to a Cu(1) site located on a third inorganic moiety to form a uniform 3-D framework (see 
<ce:float-anchor refid="fig3"></ce:float-anchor>). The ligand-supported Cu(2)⋯Cu(2)  distance is 2.839<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>Å, close to the van der Waals radius sum of the copper atom (2.8<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>Å). If the short Cu(2)⋯Cu(2) contacts between adjacent ribbons are regarded as one kind of linker, the inorganic copper chloride subunit is transformed into an extended 2-D pseudo-layer (see b), and the entire structure may be best described as a pillared-layer framework. Interestingly, the adjacent isonicotinato ligands down the <ce:italic>c</ce:italic>-axis point to two opposite positions in the interlamellar regions. Moreover, the pyridine rings located on the contraposition of each copper chloride ribbon have dihedral angles of about 82°.</ce:para>
elements.clean_text: Within the inorganic copper chloride motif, Cu(1) atoms share corners via μ4-Cl to form an infinite 1-D {Cu2Cl2} n  chain along b-axis, which was frequently encountered in copper chlorides . However, each bridging chlorine atom links to an additional Cu(2) atom, generating a novel fishbone-like 1-D copper chloride ribbon ( ). Further, every isonicotinato ligand nips two Cu(2) atoms being part of two copper chloride ribbons via its carboxyl group, and the remaining nitrogen donor of the ligand anchors to a Cu(1) site located on a third inorganic moiety to form a uniform 3-D framework (see  ). The ligand-supported Cu(2)⋯Cu(2)  distance is 2.839Å, close to the van der Waals radius sum of the copper atom (2.8Å). If the short Cu(2)⋯Cu(2) contacts between adjacent ribbons are regarded as one kind of linker, the inorganic copper chloride subunit is transformed into an extended 2-D pseudo-layer (see b), and the entire structure may be best described as a pillared-layer framework. Interestingly, the adjacent isonicotinato ligands down the c-axis point to two opposite positions in the interlamellar regions. Moreover, the pyridine rings located on the contraposition of each copper chloride ribbon have dihedral angles of about 82°.

elements.content: <ce:para view="all">It is believed that the isonicotinato ligand plays a crucial role in the formation of the novel copper chloride moiety in <ce:bold>1</ce:bold>. The distinctive coordination fashions of IN<ce:sup loc="post">−</ce:sup> are responsible for the occurrences of two types of crystallographically unique Cu centeres, which make it possible to generate new copper chloride subunits by polymerizing these metal atoms with halogens in a distinct manner. Also, as foregoing interpretations, isonicotinato ligand possesses negative charge which may dramatically influence the inorganic copper halide adducts by breaking the charge balance between Cu<ce:sup loc="post">+</ce:sup> and X<ce:sup loc="post">−</ce:sup>, resulting in the formation of a Cu:Cl<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>=<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>2:1 adduct not 1:1 product.</ce:para>
elements.clean_text: It is believed that the isonicotinato ligand plays a crucial role in the formation of the novel copper chloride moiety in 1. The distinctive coordination fashions of IN- are responsible for the occurrences of two types of crystallographically unique Cu centeres, which make it possible to generate new copper chloride subunits by polymerizing these metal atoms with halogens in a distinct manner. Also, as foregoing interpretations, isonicotinato ligand possesses negative charge which may dramatically influence the inorganic copper halide adducts by breaking the charge balance between Cu+ and X-, resulting in the formation of a Cu:Cl=2:1 adduct not 1:1 product.

elements.content: <ce:para view="all">The TG curve of compound <ce:bold>1</ce:bold> exhibits one-step continuous weight losses in the temperature range of 280–580<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>°C, as shown in , which may be due to the release of organic ligands and Cl<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>. The total weight loss of 43.1% is in good agreement with the calculated value of 44.1%.</ce:para>
elements.clean_text: The TG curve of compound 1 exhibits one-step continuous weight losses in the temperature range of 280-580°C, as shown in , which may be due to the release of organic ligands and Cl2. The total weight loss of 43.1% is in good agreement with the calculated value of 44.1%.

elements.content: <ce:para view="all">At room temperature, solid state <ce:bold>1</ce:bold> exhibits both the high- and low-energy emissions at 430<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>nm (blue region) and 614<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>nm (red region), respectively. Luminescent copper(I) systems stem from either ligand-centered, metal-centered, or charge transfer transitions . According to the literature  and structure of <ce:bold>1</ce:bold>, we suggest that the low-energy emission may come from the metal-to-ligand charge transfer transition, which is modified by the metal–metal interactions. The excited states for the high-energy emissions could have mixed character involving both ligand-centered and metal-to-ligand charge transfer transitions.</ce:para>
elements.clean_text: At room temperature, solid state 1 exhibits both the high- and low-energy emissions at 430nm (blue region) and 614nm (red region), respectively. Luminescent copper(I) systems stem from either ligand-centered, metal-centered, or charge transfer transitions . According to the literature  and structure of 1, we suggest that the low-energy emission may come from the metal-to-ligand charge transfer transition, which is modified by the metal-metal interactions. The excited states for the high-energy emissions could have mixed character involving both ligand-centered and metal-to-ligand charge transfer transitions.

elements.content: <ce:section-title>Conclusion</ce:section-title><ce:para view="all">In summary, a new inorganic–organic hybrid copper halide with isonicotinato ligands has been reported. This compound displays a unique 3-D network constructed from covalent bridging 1-D copper chloride ribbons via linear organic ligands. The successful isolation of the compound confirms that introduction of non-neutral organic ligands is an optional route for the construction of novel hybrid copper halides. Future research may focus on the attempt to explore the effects of the organic ligands on the reaction system.</ce:para>
elements.clean_text:
Conclusion

In summary, a new inorganic-organic hybrid copper halide with isonicotinato ligands has been reported. This compound displays a unique 3-D network constructed from covalent bridging 1-D copper chloride ribbons via linear organic ligands. The successful isolation of the compound confirms that introduction of non-neutral organic ligands is an optional route for the construction of novel hybrid copper halides. Future research may focus on the attempt to explore the effects of the organic ligands on the reaction system.

Synthesis of     Cu   2   I   Cl ( IN )   (1)

Compound 1 was originally prepared via a self-assembly process under mild hydrothermal condition from the reaction of CuCl, isonicotinic acid, NaCl, and H2O in a molar ratio of 2:1:1:555 at 140°C for four days. After slow cooling to room temperature, the resulting orange needles of 1 were collected as a major phase (32% yield on Cu) together with a small quantity of blue block crystals, and then filtered off, washed with distilled water, and dried at ambient temperature. The needles were manually selected for structural determination and further characterization. Anal. Calc. for 1: C, 25.32; N, 4.92; Cu, 44.65. Found: C, 25.19; N, 4.83; Cu, 44.92%. IR (KBr) ν/cm-1: 3033w, 1585s, 1547s, 1227s, 1055w, 858w, 764m, 765m, 700s and 527w ().

 reveals that the structure of compound <ce:bold>1</ce:bold> features a novel 3-D framework constructed from 1-D fishbone-like inorganic ribbons linked via linear bridging ligands IN<ce:sup loc="post">−</ce:sup>. 
<ce:float-anchor refid="fig1"></ce:float-anchor> shows the basic building unit and coordination environments around the copper atoms. Cu(1) atom, residing in a tetrahedral environment, is coordinated by three equivalent chlorine atoms and one nitrogen donor from isonicotinato ligand, whereas Cu(2) atom coordinates to one chlorine donor and two carboxyl oxygen donors from two different IN<ce:sup loc="post">−</ce:sup> to finish its T-shape coordination environment. The Cu(1)–Cl bond lengths are in the range of 2.287–2.625<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>Å (average value 2.425<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>Å), comparable with those found in other reported Cu<ce:sup loc="post">I</ce:sup>–Cl distances . However, the Cu(2)–Cl length of 2.715 is a little longer than the normal Cu<ce:sup loc="post">I</ce:sup>–Cl distance. The tetrahedrally coordinated copper atom is somewhat distorted with Cl–Cu–Cl angles varying from 104.48° to 106.69° and Cl–Cu–N angles of 98.60°, 112.27° and 125.90°, respectively.</ce:para><ce:para view="all">The TG curve of compound <ce:bold>1</ce:bold> exhibits one-step continuous weight losses in the temperature range of 280–580<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>°C, as shown in , which may be due to the release of organic ligands and Cl<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>. The total weight loss of 43.1% is in good agreement with the calculated value of 44.1%.</ce:para>
cln_elements.clean_text:
Results and discussion

Single crystal X-ray diffraction analysis 1 CCDC-253571 contains the supplementary crystallographic data for this paper. These data can be obtained free of charge at www.ccdc.cam.ac.uk/conts/retrieving.html [or from the Cambridge Crystallographic Data Centre, 12, Union Road, Cambridge CB2 1EZ, UK; fax: (internat.) +44 1223/336 033; e-mail: deposit@ccdc.cam.ac.uk].   reveals that the structure of compound 1 features a novel 3-D framework constructed from 1-D fishbone-like inorganic ribbons linked via linear bridging ligands IN-.   shows the basic building unit and coordination environments around the copper atoms. Cu(1) atom, residing in a tetrahedral environment, is coordinated by three equivalent chlorine atoms and one nitrogen donor from isonicotinato ligand, whereas Cu(2) atom coordinates to one chlorine donor and two carboxyl oxygen donors from two different IN- to finish its T-shape coordination environment. The Cu(1)-Cl bond lengths are in the range of 2.287-2.625Å (average value 2.425Å), comparable with those found in other reported CuI-Cl distances . However, the Cu(2)-Cl length of 2.715 is a little longer than the normal CuI-Cl distance. The tetrahedrally coordinated copper atom is somewhat distorted with Cl-Cu-Cl angles varying from 104.48° to 106.69° and Cl-Cu-N angles of 98.60°, 112.27° and 125.90°, respectively.

The TG curve of compound 1 exhibits one-step continuous weight losses in the temperature range of 280-580°C, as shown in , which may be due to the release of organic ligands and Cl2. The total weight loss of 43.1% is in good agreement with the calculated value of 44.1%.

decomposition temperature.type: release of organic ligands and Cl2
